text:
KDE neon is a distribution based on the latest LTS release of [Ubuntu](https://ubuntu.com) that uses the latest stable releases of the [Plasma Desktop Environment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KDE_Plasma_5).  KDE neon was created by the former project lead of Kubuntu, Jonathan Riddell.  Even though KDE neon is not an [official Ubuntu flavor](https://ubuntu.com/download/flavours), it still has access to all of the packages in Ubuntu's repositories and can use PPAs created for Ubuntu.

[Screenshots of KDE neon](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Category:KDE_neon_releases)

## <div emoji="<:SeemsGood:478441196755091461>" style="display:none;"/> Advantages of KDE neon
- Maintained by the KDE developers themselves.
- Small install size; around 1600 packages.
- Offers the latest KDE packages on a stable base.
- Plasma is the most customizable Desktop Environment for Linux.
- Usually gets Plasma updates before any other distro.

## <div emoji="<:glare:504911469943717909>" style="display:none;"/> Disadvantages of KDE neon
- **Very** frequent package updates, so may not be great for people who are not computer savvy.
- May run into bugs due to frequent Plasma package updates.

## <div emoji="<:think:585665071938666508>" style="display:none;"/> Should You Use KDE neon?
If you are looking for the latest KDE Plasma packages on a stable base, KDE neon is the distribution for you.  KDE neon is extremely customizable, stable, and fairly easy to use.  Please only use the `User Edition` of KDE neon as the other two versions are not intended for normal use.

[Download KDE neon](https://files.kde.org/neon/images/user/current/neon-user-current.iso.mirrorlist)

## Updating KDE neon
- Instead of using `apt upgrade`, it is recommended to use `apt full-upgrade` to avoid problems with updates.
- Contrary to what KDE neon recommends on their website, `pkcon` is ***not recommended***.  `pkcon` is buggy when used in a terminal.

## Ubuntu Driver Manager
- After installing KDE neon, you can install Ubuntu's driver manager by running the following command in a terminal: `sudo apt install software-properties-gtk`
- Then find Software & Updates in your menu and switch to the Additional Drivers tab.

See <div emoji="`{prefix}info ubuntu`" style="display:none;"/>[Ubuntu](#ubuntu) for more information about Ubuntu.
